case_name: M/s Gotan Lime Syndicate v. Commissioner of Income Tax

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 692 to 694 of 1964 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 692 to 694 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeals directed against judgment and order dated October 9, 1963 of Rajasthan High Court in D.B. Civil Income-tax Reference No. 73 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated October 9, 1963 of the Rajasthan High Court in D. B. Civil Income-tax Reference No. 73 of 1961.

facts.text: Reference made by Income Tax Appellate Tribunal, Bombay Branch, under S. 66 of Indian Income Tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: judgment of the Rajasthan High Court in a consolidated reference made to it by the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal, Bombay Branch, under S. 66(1) of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922 hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: Question referred: whether sum of Rs. 96,000 paid by assessee during each relevant accounting years was rightly allowed as revenue deduction.

anchor.surface_text: The question referred to by the Appellate Tribunal is as follows whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case. the sum of Rs. 96,000 paid by the assessee during each of the relevant accounting,, years was rightly allowed as a revenue deduction

facts.text: Appellant M/s Gotan Lime Syndicate is a registered firm carrying on business of manufacturing lime from limestone.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, M s Gotan Lime Syndicate, hereinafter referred to as the assessee, is a registered firm and carries on the business of manufacturing lime from lime-stone.

facts.text: By indenture dated March 4, 1949, assessee granted right to excavate limestone in Gotan and Tunkaliyan areas.

anchor.surface_text: By an indenture dated March 4, 1949, the assessee was granted the right to excavate lime-stone in certain area at Gotan and Tunkaliyan, subject to certain conditions.

facts.text: Original lease expired on July 14, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: except that the lease expired on July 14, 1952.

facts.text: Lease extended from time to time, last extension by letter dated December 17, 1952 up to 31st March 1953 or finalisation of proposals, whichever shorter.

anchor.surface_text: The lease was extended from time to time by the Government for short periods. The last letter dated December 17, 1952, extending the lease was in the following terms

facts.text: Government letter dated December 1, 1953 intimated new policy for leasing limestone quarries: blocks of 5 sq miles, dead rent Rs.10/acre, royalty Re.1/- per md, 5 years renewable 5, min 10 max 30 sq miles.

anchor.surface_text: By letter dated December 1, 1953, the Government intimated to. the Director of Mines and Geology, Rajasthan, Udaipur, that the Government had adopted a new policy for leasing out lime-stone quarries. The proposal Was to divide the lime- stone quarries in Jodhpur Division in blocks of 5 sq. miles each and the dead rent was to be charged at Rs. 10/- per acre while royalty was to be charged at Re. -/1/- per md. of lime-stone.

facts.text: On October 4, 1954, Government sanctioned leasing 15 sq miles of lime deposits to assessee.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on October 4, 1954, the Government sanctioned the leasing out of 15 sq. miles of lime deposits to the assessee.

facts.text: Arrears payment from 30-7-52 decided at Rs.96,000 per year based on dead rent for 15 sq miles at Rs.10/acre, agreed by assessee before Chief Minister.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the payment of arrears by M s Gotan Lime Syndicate for the period between 30-7-52, and the date the new lease is given effect to, it has been decided that they may pay Rs. 96,000/ Rupees Ninety six thousand  per year which has also been agreed to by them before the Chief Minister  Industries  on the basis of dead rent under the new proposals for 15 sq. miles at Rs. 10/- per acre.

facts.text: Assessee never executed any lease but continued to work the lime deposits.

anchor.surface_text: It further appears that the assessee never executed any lease but continued,to work the lime deposits

facts.text: Payments finalised by letter dated November 30, 1959 from Mining Engineer, Jodhpur.

anchor.surface_text: and the payments to be made were finalised by letter dated November 30, 1959 from the Mining Engineer, Jodhpur, to the assesee.

facts.text: Royalty settled at Rs.96,000 per year for 1953-54 to 1958-59 despite lower accrued royalty based on exports.

anchor.surface_text: On checking the figures of export of lime stone, limekali and lime kachra for the settlement of royalty, the figures of royalty amount payable in the following years is as under - From 1st April Year Export figures Amount, to 31st March Rs. as. p. 1953-54 13511 tons30,553 10 6 ... At the end of each financial year the accrued royalty amount is far less actually and as such as per agreement royalty payable is Rs. 96,000/- in all the years above written.

facts.text: Terms on which assessee remained in possession are contained in Jodhpur Division Vindhyan Limestone Mining Leases Rules, 1954 and Rajasthan Minor Mineral Concession Rules, 1955; common ground.

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that these terms are contained in the Jodhpur Division Vindhyan Lime-stone Mining Leases Rules, 1954, and the Rajasthan Minor Mineral Concession Rules, 1955.

facts.text: For assessment years 1954-55, 1955-56, 1956-57, assessee paid Rs.96,000 each to Government and claimed as revenue deduction.

anchor.surface_text: For each of the assessment years 1954-55, 1955-56 and 1956-57, the assessee paid a sum of Rs. 96,000/- to Government and claimed it as a revenue deduction against its profits for those years.

facts.text: Income Tax Officer disallowed the Rs.96,000 expenditure as capital nature.

anchor.surface_text: The Income Tax Officer disallowed this expenditure, as being of a capital nature.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld ITO's view.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld his view,

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal held payment as revenue expenditure.

anchor.surface_text: but on appeal, the Appellate Tribunal held that the payment should be treated as a revenue expenditure.

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court held payment as capital expenditure, not deductible.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held on a reference that the payment was capital expenditure and could not be allowed as a revenue deduction in computing the business profit of the assessee.

facts.text: Supreme Court held yearly payment of Rs.96,000 as revenue expenditure.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the yearly payment of Rs. 96,000/- should be treated as revenue expenditure and the answer to the question referred to the High Court must be in favour of the assessee.

facts.text: Assessee entitled to go upon the land, win raw material, build premises under arrangement and rules.

anchor.surface_text: Under the arrangement, read with the Rajasthan Minor Mineral Concession Rules, 1955, the assessee was certainly entitled to go upon the land, win the raw-material and had some rights to build premises for the purpose of winning the lime.

facts.text: No lumpsum payment was ever settled or paid.

anchor.surface_text: No lumpsum payment was ever settled or paid.
under S. 66 1  of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922  hereinafter referred to as the Act .

arguments.claim: Circumstances do not fall within Viscount Cave test because no payment once for all but yearly payment of dead rent and royalty

anchor.surface_text: The question then arises whether the circumstances of this case fall within the test laid down by Viscount Cave and relied on strongly by the learned Attorney-General. In our opinion, the test does not apply fully to this case because there is no payment once for all it is a yearly payment of deadrent and royalty.

arguments.claim: No lumpsum payment was ever settled or paid; no case where royalty under mining lease treated as capital expenditure

anchor.surface_text: No lumpsum payment was ever settled or paid. We have not been referred to any case in which payments of royalty under a mining lease have been treated as capital expenditure.

arguments.claim: Royalty payments would be allowable as deductions on revenue account

anchor.surface_text: There is, of course, no doubt that those rents or royalty payments would be allowable as deductions on revenue account.

arguments.claim: In Pingle royalty payments allowed as revenue; dispute only lumpsum

anchor.surface_text: In Pingle Industries Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income Tax the assessee had already been allowed payments of royalty as revenue expenditure and the only dispute was regarding lumpsum payment.

arguments.claim: Reason royalty allowed as revenue is its relation to raw material excavated or extracted; more taken more paid; dead rent advance for raw material

anchor.surface_text: The reason why royalty has to be allowed as revenue expenditure must be the relation which the royalty has to the raw-material which is going to be excavated or extracted. The more you take the more royalty you pay, and the minimum payment or the deadrent also has the same characteristic,

arguments.claim: Abdul Kayoom distinguishable because payments had no relation to amount of chankshell taken; speculative right to fish

anchor.surface_text: We find that it is on this ground that the case strongly relied on by the learned Attorney-General Abdul Kayoom v. Commissioner of Income Tax is distinguishable because payments there had no relation whatsoever to the amount of chankshells taken.

arguments.claim: Pingle distinguishable because lumpsum payment in instalments for acquiring capital asset of enduring benefit

anchor.surface_text: The case of Pingle Industries Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income Tax is distinguishable because on the facts it was a lumpsum payment in instalments for acquiring capital asset of enduring benefit to his trade.

arguments.claim: Not in every case enduring advantage means capital expenditure; forward contract for raw material supply over years is revenue

anchor.surface_text: It is not the law that in every case, if an enduring advantage is obtained the expenditure for securing it must be treated as capital expenditure, for as pointed out by Channell, J., in Allanza Company v. Bell in the ordinary case, the cost of the material worked up in a manufactory is not a capital expenditure it is a current expenditure,

arguments.claim: Special circumstances leading to opposite conclusion as acknowledged by Viscount Cave; here royalty relates to raw material not acquisition of enduring advantage

anchor.surface_text: Viscount Cave acknowledged that in certain cases an expenditure for obtaining an enduring advantage need not be capital expenditure for he inserted the words in the absence of special circumstances leading to an opposite conclusion within brackets. We are of the opinion that in the present case the royalty payment is not a direct payment for securing an enduring advantage it has relation to the raw material to be obtained.

arguments.claim: No material to show any part of royalty as premium referable to acquisition of mining lease

anchor.surface_text: No material has been placed on the record to show that any part of the royalty must, in view of the circumstances of the case, be treated as premium and be referable to the acquisition of the mining lease.
